detail.content: Movies 101                                                                                          The NYU School of Professional Studies Website    Faculty    Degrees    Professional Certificates    Upcoming Events        Search Courses     Credit Course     Non-Credit Course          Site    Noncredit Courses    Faculty                                                                       Humanities, Arts, and Writing                                                                                           About             Director's Message Faculty News                   Admissions                 Academics             M.S. in Professional Writing Noncredit Offerings                   Career                 Events             Art Law Day Art Crime Symposium                   Highlights             Movies 101 Modern British Drama in London Oxford University Study Program                                                     Movies 101                                            Highlights ›                Movies 101            Modern British Drama in London            Oxford University Study Program                                                                                                  Movies 101                                   Movies 101 ® takes you up close and personal to the best new releases, giving you direct access to today’s top filmmakers in person. Join Professor Richard Brown for exclusive screenings of the latest indie gems and studio blockbusters in the series Time Magazine called "a virtual feast for the film lover."   After each movie, Professor Brown introduces the star, the director—or frequently both—for a round of insightful, and compelling conversation.   Recent guests have included Martin Scorsese, Meryl Streep, Javier Bardem, and George Clooney—and the Movies 101 audience was among the first to see The Artist , The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel , Bridesmaids , Crazy Stupid Love , The Five-Year Engagement , Hugo , The King's Speech , Margin Call , Moneyball , Undefeated , War Horse , among others.   Call (212) 998-7150 to register for one of our courses! Comedy Writing: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Comedy Writing for Film and Television  FMTV-UT.1158 Studio 4 Credits Course Level: Advanced (formerly Advanced Comedy Writing Workshop)      Prerequisite: Fundamentals of Dramatic and Visual Writing (H56.0033), or Dramatic & Visual Writing II (H56.0032), or Script Writing II (H56.0056). Starting Spring 2010, this course will require Writing the Short Screenplay (H56.1020) or Script Analysis (H56.1084). Course may be repeated.    In this course you will have the opportunity to write: comedy feature film, half-hour sitcom specs scripts, series of comedy sketches and stand-up comedy material. This intimate class is a writing workshop that explores every aspect of comedy writing for visual media. Whether it’s Larry David that does it for you, or the Brothers Farrelly, Marx or Coen, this course will help students discover what works, what doesn’t, and why. The last part of the semester will be devoted to the business of comedy writing – where the work is, who the players are. Industry guest speakers may visit throughout the semester. 2014 Graduate Screenplay Showcase: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing About the Program/Admissions Admissions Student Life Course Offerings News & Events Work of Writing Students Screenplay Showcase Fellowships/Contests Script Bank Sloan Winners Admin & Faculty Alumni Internships Contact  home > Dramatic Writing        2014 Graduate Screenplay Showcase  The NYU Department of Dramatic Writing presents the finalists for the 2014 Screenplay Showcase (Graduate Students): the top feature-length screenplays written by the Graduating Class of 2014. If you are interested in reading any of the screenplays below, please contact the writer directly. THE METHOD  Written by April Elizabeth Brassard Genre: Psychological Thriller Logline: Actor Logan Beaumont, Hollywood’s go-to “Pretty Boy,” decides to   challenge the industry’s perception of him by going after the lead part   in a renowned director’s newest film about the life of a   serial killer which causes Logan to spiral   into a deep depression, and because of his training as a method actor,   to eventually become so consumed by the role that he becomes a killer   himself.  more  E-mail: aeb551@nyu.edu  A CURIOUS BOND  Written by Samantha Charlip Genre: Historical Drama Logline: Based on a true story, the friendship between L. Ron Hubbard and rocket scientist Jack Parsons leads them both in explosive directions. Bio: Samantha Charlip is a New York based writer and former Producer for television networks including A&E, Turner and Viacom. Awards include: Finalist: O’Neill National Playwrights Conference, more  E-mail: samantha.charlip@gmail.com Portfolio Website: http://www.behance.net/samanthacharlip  CINERIBUS  Written by Nick Coston Genre: Crime Thriller Logline:    In the crumbling infrastructure of Detroit, a weary firefighter pursues   an arsonist who claims to want what's best for the beleaguered city: a   fresh start from a purge of fire.    Bio: Nick Coston is an Americ an MFA candidate in Dramatic   Writing at NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. He graduated with honors with   degrees in creative writing more  E-mail: nccoston@gmail.com  PENALTY  Written by Krystal Foster Genre: Crime Drama Logline: A mother’s life shatters when her star football player son is found guilty of rape and demands he accepts his fate... until she discovers that his accusers manufactured his destiny leading to her own investigation where she uncovers a corrupt system, but realizes she may ultimately be part of the problem. Bio: Born and raised in California, Krystal Foster has been involved in the performing arts and entertainment industry for over 20 years. more E-mail: knf238@nyu.edu  THE GREEN TIE  Written by Ashley Griggs Genre: Family Drama/Thriller Logline: When 18-year-old Darci discovers that her loving father may have a second family, she pursues the truth, but finds that her father’s double life is more sinister than she could have ever imagined. Bio:    Ashley Griggs was born in Herndon, Virginia and spent her childhood   days conjuring up imaginary worlds and narrating her life on her   parents’ ten-pound video camera. more E-mail: adg303@nyu.edu  SO TWO YEARS AGO  Written by Alex M. Langenfeld Genre: Comedy  Log Line:    When a struggling comic book artist is forced to return to Chicago and   come face to face with his ex-wife, his wild imagination brings his 15   year old self to the present. He's gotta team up with his inner child if   he's gonna win the girl back.    Bio: Alex M Langenfeld is a Minnesota boy, earning his BA in   Film from Columbia College Chicago and his MFA in Dramatic Writing from   NYU's Tisch more    Email: AmlCorporate@gmail.com Twitter: @ corporatemalice Blog: corporatemalice.tumblr.com  RESIDUAL EFFECTS  Written by Dan Marmor Genre: Conspiracy Thriller Logline: Year: 2076. When smalltime actor John plays a mourner in a fake massacre, his life is in the balance as he attempts to expose the truth about legislative-manipulation. Bio: Dan Marmor received his BA from Stanford University in English and Creative Writing and his MFA from NYU Tisch School of the Arts in Dramatic Writing. E-mail: Dpm277@nyu.edu  VILLA OF LIFE  Written by Juan Ramirez Genre: Horror  Log   Line: Colette is haunted by an unfortunate past that leads her to   suicidal thoughts, yet when she seeks rehabilitation at an Alive   Wellness center in Pompeii, she discovers that her treatment is actually   leading her to her death.     Bio: Juan Ramirez is an international playwright and is a producing member of The Bronx  Repertory Company. He is also the founder of The PlayPen, more  E-mail: jmr766@nyu.edu  MOLLY PITCHER  Written by Brigette ReDavid Genre: Historical Drama Logline: Based on the true   story of Molly Pitcher, a brave woman who fought in the Revolutionary War, whose epic battle isn't only with the British. Bio: Life, whether it's funny, childish, suspenseful or bitter, provides an endless supply of story ideas, especially for former journalist Brigette ReDavid more E-mail: brigette@redavid.net  PUPPETS INCORPORATED  Written by Swee San Logline: After his brother Paul dies while serving in the army, Leonard makes an anti-government rap video criticising the Ministry of Defence. The video gets the attention of both the ruling and opposition parties, and Leonard becomes a mole and pawn. Leonard falls in love with a member of the ruling party and finds himself torn between loyalty and love. Bio: Swee San is a Singaporean who did her undergraduate studies in the United States. She is a Screenwriting Major at TischAsia. She loves to bring out the comedy in tragedies and the tragic in comedies. E-mail: ngsweesan@ymail.com; ssn262@nyu.edu  MOTHER  Written by Nick Savvides Genre: Psychological Horror Logline: When a 13 year old boy and his 9 year old sister discover that their recently divorced mother has been turned into a vampire, they must decide whether to kill her to save themselves, or protect her to keep the family together. Bio: Nick Savvides is a screenwriter and TV writer from the United Kingdom with an intense passion for cinema. more  E-mail: nick_savvides@hotmail.co.uk Twitter: @ nicksav  ON THE VERGE  Written by Tanisha Sharma Genre: Drama Logline:    Twenty-three year old Sasha is pressurized to try for a child again   soon after she suffers from a miscarriage. She finds solace and freedom   in a wedding invite from her school friend and travels to Melbourne, to   escape her parents and husband. Sasha unknowingly embarks upon a journey   of independence that comes with a price. Through her struggles, she   tries to live a life she missed out on, finding new love and coming to   terms with her loss. more  E-mail: tishkaboom@gmail.com  THE EMPIRE BUILDER  Written by Ashley Sims Genre: Historical Drama Logline: Ambitious young architect, Albert Speer, is given the chance of a lifetime to work with the up-and-coming Third Reich in 1930s Germany; but when he is brought into Hitler’s inner circle, the ideals he once stood for are challenged and he must choose what side he is truly on before it’s too late. Based on a true story. Bio: Ashley Sims earned her MFA from Tisch in 2014 where she received the   Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Award for more  E-mail: ashleysims07@gmail.com Phone: 917.225.4243 Twitter: @ ashsims  GENERICS  Written by Cory Terry Genre: Comedy Logline: When a mysterious generic-brand soapmaker offers a meek factory   worker $2 million to steal his company's special soap formula, the   worker must outwit his greedy boss to pilfer the secret recipe without   losing his job...and going to prison. Bio: Cory Terry was raised in the tactfully named city of Plantation, Florida. He has written several half-hour television pilots and screenplays, including "Generics," which was a semi-finalist in the 2013 Page International Screenwriting Awards. more  E-mail: corywterry@gmail.com   2014 Undergraduate Screenplay Showcase 2014 Screenplay Showcase Winners           Undergraduate Admissions Graduate Admissions Academic Services Student Life Financial Aid and Scholarships Career Development Counseling Services International Students Incoming Students Graduation Forms What is Special Programs?
